We really suggest watching the video above. It's faster, easier, and more fun than reading this whole page!
Frank Zappa lived an insane life. Rock star. Artist. Composer. Activist. Talking head. Family man. Jokester. Absurdist. One of the greatest musicians who ever lived. Even if you don’t know anything about him, you’ve probably heard his name and seen his face.
And now, for the first time, we have something no one has ever had: 
Unrestricted access to his never-before-explored, private archives. 
We're at the brink of unlocking thousands of hours of unreleased footage, and hundreds of boxes of tape, and unnameable other stuff that has been literally locked away under the Zappa family home like a time capsule since Frank’s death in 1993.
It’s time to tell Frank's DEFINITIVE STORY, like it's never been told, and to bring some of this unseen material into the world. 
Waiting inside the Vault, there's more material than we could ever fit in a single film.. but there's a challenge. 
If we don't work fast, this won't just be our first chance to see what's in the Vault... it might also be our last chance.
See, most of the contents of the Vault exist in OLD, OBSOLETE and AGING MEDIA FORMATS: tape, film, video, paper, and other outdated forms of media that are deteriorating even as we speak. 
In order to use and share this stuff, we first have to access it, catalog it, find the best stuff, digitize and preserve it, and then edit it. And all of that takes time, money and patience.
That's why we're asking all of Frank's fans to get involved, and to help us get this done now. 
The more we raise, the more we can do... and now that we've passed our MINIMUM GOAL of $500,000, our challenge is to keep going as far as we can, so that we can save more at-risk materials and get more of the movie done. 
For those of you who decide to join me, save the Vault, and help tell Frank's story, I've got good news: you'll get a lot more than the satisfaction of helping preserve Frank's legacy. 
Whether you just want to follow along, or want a once-in-a-lifetime Zappa experience, we've got you covered with a ton of great, exclusive rewards, including...
TRACKS 10 & UP: A FRONT ROW SEAT to follow along as I start exploring the Vault. I have no idea what we'll find, but I know it'll be crazy... and that I want to share the experience with you guys! 
TRACKS 25 & UP: A DIGITAL VAULT PASS, granting you exclusive access to a backers-only archive of downloadable material selected from what I find in the Vault.

And remember: the more we raise, the more we can save, and the more you'll get to see, hear and keep!
TRACKS 35 & UP: THE DOCUMENTARY that you're helping make, available as a digital download (Tracks 35+) and in a Collector's Edition DVD or BLU-RAY (Tracks 150+), packed with bonus material and limited edition packaging.
TRACKS 50 & UP: EXCLUSIVE WTFIFZ MERCH, featuring new artwork created just for this Kickstarter campaign, and never available again! It's like a killer concert merch table, without ever leaving home! Rewards include T-SHIRTS (Track 50+), POSTERS (Track 125+) and more.
And with the help of Frank's family and friends, we’ve got some incredible, once-in-a-lifetime opportunities and rewards for true Zappa fans:
TRACK 2500: OWN FRANK'S STUFF. The Zappas have generously allowed us to offer a very limited number of items from Frank's private collection, including original filmstrips from the Vault and a few of his personal possessions.
TRACK 6000: EXPLORE FRANK'S VAULT. You'll get a private tour of the legendary Joe's Garage and the relocated Vault from me and Ahmet Zappa. Be the first person to see some of the unreleased material, then discuss it over a private lunch with me and my producing partner, Glen Zipper.
TRACK 7500: RECORD WITH FRANK'S GUITAR. Come play Frank’s guitar for a private recording session with Joe "Vaultmeister" Travers at the legendary Joe’s Garage!
So, who the fuck is Frank Zappa? Even now, 23 years after his death, the man is still a fascinating pile of contradictions. If you haven't watched the video, just consider these ten facts about Zappa:
1. He was one of the biggest rock stars of the '70s...
2. But he didn't do drugs. Ever.
3. He conducted and composed for orchestras ...
4. But he also went on national TV and played a bicycle.
5. He got banned from SNL...
6. But he was a regular on CNN.
7. He took on the government over censorship.
8. He basically invented Rock the Vote.
9. He was the face of an actual revolution in Czechoslovakia.
10. He almost ran for President in 1992.
And that doesn't begin to cover Frank's life, career, or prolific output as a performer, composer or visual artist. His work crossed genres. He made people uncomfortable. His ideas and attitudes made him revered by some, despised by others, and a source of perpetual fascination and inspiration... until, in 1993, his life was cut short by prostate cancer.
When he died at the age of 52, Zappa had already released 60 albums, and created enough music to fill 42 more posthumous albums... and counting! He'd also had four kids, influenced a generation of artists, scientists and thought leaders, and left his unique stamp on the world. 
And all of that? That's just the tip of the iceberg.
That's why this project is so important. Frank Zappa was a million different things, and for the first time, we have access to everything he kept in his private archives – thousands of hours of audio and video recordings, plus countless shelves filled with boxes of documents, photos, art and more. Using all of that material, I want to finally tell his definitive story, and help answer the question: 

Who the Fuck is Frank Zappa?
And, even better... we want you to join us. 
Frank Zappa was one of the most prolific artists of our time, and rows upon rows of floor-to-ceiling stacks of tape, video clips, film footage, and more, have been locked away under the historic Zappa house in the Hollywood Hills since Frank's death in 1993. 
No one has ever heard or seen the vast majority of this material, much less cataloged it, and it is literally crumbling against time in the Zappa's private archive: a massive underground storage chamber known as "The Vault."
By backing this campaign, you'll help us digitize and preserve (!) these archives for use in this documentary — not to mention for limited, gradual release and distribution, and the enjoyment of Zappa fans for generations to come. The more we raise, the more of Frank's unexplored archives we can save.
Hey, I'm Alex. I’m an actor / director, and in the last few years I’ve made two other documentaries about cultural influencers; Downloaded (about Napster) and Deep Web (about the hidden Internet). I’ve been a big fan of Frank Zappa’s music my whole life, but it took some time to realize that in addition to being a singular artist, he’s flat-out one of the most brilliant, hilarious, wild and fascinating renaissance men of the century. 
Shortly before she died, his widow Gail gave me unprecedented access to Frank’s life (and Vault), and her blessing to make the first all-access doc about Frank — a one-of-a-kind honor. For this project, I’ll be interviewing everyone I can who had any kind of connection to Frank, and painstakingly going through the Vault to preserve and archive the stuff I think tells Frank’s untold story best.
I've also written more about why I launched this project.
As a documentary producer who’s had the privilege of working on a diverse slate of films including Undefeated, All Things Must Pass, Deep Web, The Last Play at Shea, The Nightmare, and Foo Fighters: Back and Forth, one of the questions I am asked most is, “If you could make any documentary you wanted to do, what would it be?” My answer has always been the same, “The definitive, no-holds barred Frank Zappa doc.” Last year someone finally asked me a follow-up question that I should’ve already asked myself: “What’s stopping you?” And that, my friends, is where our journey began. 
It’s been a whirlwind for Alex and I ever since, working every day to lay the foundation of everything we need to make this dream possible. Now, together with you, I want to make a film that is not only a worthy historical document of Frank’s remarkable legacy, but also a kick-ass cinematic experience that no one will ever be able to put in a traditional documentary box.
Joe is not only a musician who's been playing with the Zappas (and other incredible bands) since the early '90s; he's also the “Vaultmeister” — keeper of Frank's archives, and expert on all things FZ. He has been the lone guardian of the Vault's material for years, chipping away at cataloguing and preserving what he can as well as co-producing the FZ delicacies released by the Zappa Family Trust.

STRETCH GOALS!
In just 16 days you guys got us to the first goal of $50K! Thank you all so very much! This means we'll be able to animate the first 15 minutes of 'The Glassworker'!

But we aren't stopping there!
THANK YOU! Our first stretch goal has been hit! 
With $75K we can have a full orchestra record the score for 'The Glassworker' Part One! 
Those of you who have pledged $50 and above will get an incredible listening experience with our Original Soundtrack.
THANK YOU! Our second stretch goal has been hit!
With $100K we'll be able to make 'The Glassworker' Part Two (Half the film!). 
 THANK YOU! Our third stretch goal has been hit!
With $110K production 'The Glassworker' Part Three can begin. The more you pledge the more of the film we can make!
Bonus stretch goal 
With $115K we will focus on making an extensive behind the scenes documentary showing how we were able to setup our animation studio in Pakistan. 
We will also have a press conference in Karachi in late May 2016 to showcase our work and invite talent to be a part of Mano Animation Studios. 
We have so many surprises for everyone! We can't wait to reveal it all to you. Help us reach our stretch goals to see what else we have planned!
Thank you for your support! 
'The Glassworker' is a coming of age story about a young boy named Vincent, who is learning the art of Glassblowing from his father in their Glass Shop. As he grows older he begins to fall in love with a frequent visitor of the shop - a young girl named Alliz. 
The film will follow both Vincent and Alliz through their developing years as life gets more complicated and inhibits their relationship. 
'The Glassworker' is a hand-drawn animated film written and directed by Usman Riaz. 
It will be Pakistan's first fully hand drawn animated film. 
Currently launching the first part through Kickstarter, Usman invites us to see his vision come to life with his team of animators, artists, and musicians formed under his newly formed ‘Mano Animation Studios’.
Young Vincent in the Workshop
Alliz in the Glass Shop
Mano Animation Studios comprises of a small team of incredibly talented artists in Pakistan who are making 'The Glassworker' come to life.
The team originates from Pakistan and extends to the United States, Malaysia, United Kingdom and South Africa.
Pakistan has no hand drawn animation industry. But with this film and our studio, we hope to lay the foundation for artists to come and work on beautiful works of art that they can be proud of. 
Mano Animation Studios means that we can support new work, and seed opportunities to support a new generation of exceptional artists in Pakistan, and beyond.
Mano Animation Department in Pakistan
Animating in Pakistan
The Glass Rose
 
RAISING $50,000
We're grateful for every pledge towards the making of 'The Glassworker'. 
Quality is something we will not compromise on. To achieve that, we have searched and hired the people who could help us achieve this vision and maintain a standard of excellence that the story deserves.
If successful, the Kickstarter will be used to support our talented team. We have graciously been provided with a stable office/studio environment office that the Pakistan team need to to continue their work. Our team of artists have agreed to a modest fee which will enable them to still work through the first steps of the production.
Of course, any money raised above and beyond our target would mean expanding the team and supporting them with more equipment to deliver an earlier release of The Glassworker - Part One.
THE REWARDS
There are rewards for everyone.
Our rewards include both digital and exclusive experiences, with features of the music and art from the film itself.
Artwork & Wallpapers
Limited Edition Artbooks & Original Soundtrack
'The Making of the Glassworker' book will give readers insight into how the film was made and will show everything from character designs to architectural models made by the team of artists.
Character Sheet for 'Mr. Oliver'
Model of the Glass Shop
'The Glassworker Storyboards' will show each shot drawn and described by Usman Riaz.
Drawing the storyboards
'Paper' the app on the iPad Pro have been a key part in helping Usman create detailed storyboards and sketches. We will be giving these storyboards and sketches as special rewards to our backers! 
Sample from 'The Glassworker Storyboards'
The Score for 'The Glassworker' will be written by Usman with compositions featuring the Piano, Strings and Glockenspiel to evoke the nature of Glass.
The soundtrack and books will be given as digital and physical rewards.
We also will hold invite events in Pakistan and New York, where you will get a chance to meet the amazing team behind the film.
The global team will also be sharing their video series: “Making The Glassworker“ for our online community to share the production experience.
 
ABOUT THE DIRECTOR  
Usman Riaz at Mano
TED Senior Fellow Usman Riaz is a fine-artist, multi-instrumentalist and composer who is passionate about the creative process and using technology to rapidly further our talents.

Currently based in Boston, Usman has been acclaimed for captivating audiences around the world with his storytelling through film and music.

campaign.story:
Columbia Gorge Getaways is the first everything-you-need guidebook for vacations in the Columbia River Gorge, one of the nation’s nine National Scenic Areas. The gorge begins 17 miles east of Portland and runs another 80 miles to the east. 
In itinerary format, the book lays out great places to wine-tour, shop, sample the brew pubs, visit historic sites and museums, soak in hot mineral waters, explore scenic back roads, whitewater raft, learn to windsurf (or watch experts), bike, swim, hike behind a waterfall or in an ancient forest, or take a train ride, aerial tour or boat cruise. It's all in the gorge, and all in the book. 
Cape Horn in April, near the end of the rainy season. Drive to this overlook in Tour 1, or even better, hike Cape Horn, also in Tour 1.
The glove-boxed size resource offers 12 itineraries of 36 to 72 hours, each centered on one of the gorge’s historic riverfront towns. Trips are designed for family vacations, solo explorations or romantic adventures. The cost of outings ranges from free to up there.
Choose one of the rewards--a copy of the book or an interpretive walk or bike ride--and you'll help fund the print run in March 2016. Whether you choose a reward or not, thank you for looking at my page.
Evolution of this book
In fall 2013, Friends of the Columbia Gorge asked me to write a book that’d promote connections between the gorge’s hiking trails and its towns. Friends is a 5,000-member advocacy/educational nonprofit and land conservancy. Towns to Trails is a long-range program to build a gorge-wide trail network that also incorporates public transit. Some Towns to Trails segments are complete--they're in the book--and more are coming.
During months of field research and drafts, the book's scope expanded beyond this, and I wrestled with how to best present all the ways a person can have a blast in the gorge. For a while, I was working on a geographic model: showing recreation options as you traveled from Portland to points east, along with a listing of activities by topic. 
Bike to this viewpoint on the Historic Columbia River Highway State Trail, in Tour 9. The view: Coyote Wall, a huge fault in the earth's crust on the Washington side. (Explore it in Tour 5.)
But that still meant you, the reader, had to do a lot of planning and page-flipping. I wanted to make a gorge vacation pure pleasure--from the moment you have the idea to go, to the minute you return to your front door. 
I decided to do the planning for you, and settled on an itinerary format so you don't have to spend hours crafting a gorge vacation: just grab the book, dream a bit, maybe make a reservation or two, and then go.
The 13 gorge towns have 13 very diverse personalities. Hood River, a more athletic version of Portland, is world-famous for its windsurfing, orchards and beer. Washougal has the iconic Pendleton Woolen Mills, an awesome river beach and a tavern called Bigfoot. The Dalles occupies land inhabited for 10,000 years, and has one of the gorge's best museums and historic downtowns. You can walk to the point where Oregon Trail pioneers launched their lives into the Columbia, and climb Pulpit Rock, where missionaries preached to Native Americans in the 1830s. 
Each town has much to love. Each one becomes your base for a vacation. 
Wind Mountain, one of the gorge's most prominent landmarks. From Tour 4, Carson and Gifford Pinchot National Forest.
Many gorge visitor are like me: I’d been hiking there since I moved to Oregon 27 years ago, but my forays hadn't expanded much beyond wildflower and waterfall hikes. 
For this book, I spent 18 months biking, swimming, hiking, eating, drinking, exploring and researching. I read armloads of books on the gorge’s cultural and natural history—nuggets of which are interspersed throughout my book, wherever it's most relevant to you as a visitor. 
In the style of my Portland guidebooks, I created urban biking and walking routes within the gorge towns, so you could explore, shop, eat and get a real sense of the place.
The result is a book that gives you what you look for in a vacation: a variety of experiences, indoors and out, from free to value-added, from strenuous to mellow, from obvious highlights to the quietest pathways, beaches and back roads. 
I believe travelers to the gorge shouldn't just hike and hightail it back to Portland for dinner. Columbia Gorge Getaways gives you a no-stress path to a multi-day escape while supporting the great gorge towns whose backyards have become a national playground.
About the book
The book's tours cover the entire gorge, on both sides of the Columbia, from temperate rainforest to desert, and from river beach to cliff top, from hostel and brewpub to luxury resort and wine tour.
Bike to beer, beach and this view atop a bluff in Tour 10, Hood River.
The book is 224 pages: 12 chapters, 21 maps, 60 historic and contemporary photos, and three appendices that cover gear rentals, lessons, outfitters, excursions, festivals, and alt transportation. It will retail for $19.95 and be available wherever books are sold, as well as direct from Friends of the Columbia Gorge. See the "About the book" heading for the table of contents and sample text.
The book has been written and edited. Maps are finished. At Feb. 3, 2016, design and layout are underway. The Kickstarter campaign, if successful, will pay for the print run in March 2016.
Pack a picnic and get close to expert windsurfers at Washington's Spring Creek National Fish Hatchery. Tour 5: White Salmon and Bingen
Follow each tour's itinerary as closely or as loosely as you want. In the book you’ll find where in the gorge to:  
eat Northwest-grown food, and drink local wine, beer, spirits and cider, in brewpubs, tasting rooms and vineyards
After you shop in Cascade Locks or hike or bike the Historic Columbia River Highway State Trail, eat near the Bridge of the Gods at Thunder Island Brewing in Tour 11.
cruise scenic back roads to wineries, viewpoints and orchards
Share the road with cows on scenic routes laid down by footsteps of Oregon Trail pioneers in Tour 8, The Dalles.
rent bikes and ride one of the nation’s most scenic car-free routes, the Historic Columbia River Highway State Trail
No cars, big views: bike the Historic Columbia River Highway State Trail in Tour 9, Mosier.
discover local history, geology and culture at historic sites, landmarks and an eclectic bunch of museums and visitor centers
Visit Herman the 6-foot sturgeon, feed hatchery fish and trout, watch ships pass through locks, and tour classic WPA architecture at Bonneville Dam, a National Historic Landmark. Drive or bike there in Tour 11.
Walk the same beaches as Lewis, Clark and Sacagawea. Here replica canoes mark their campsite, seen on a flat bike ride in Tour 1, Washougal and Cape Horn.
shop in quaint downtowns full of galleries and stores selling casual wear, gifts, crafts, jewelry, books and sports gear 
Goldendale's Art Deco courthouse is one of many architectural gems in gorge towns. In Tour 6: Lyle, Maryhill and Goldendale Observatory State Park.
play on a river beach, raft a whitewater river, and take a kayak, SUP or windsurfing lesson 
Wade, swim and beach walk at Sand Island in the Columbia River on Tour 12.
find an ancient forest to walk and sleep in
At Government Mineral Springs, in Tour 4. This tree came down but many ancient ones still stand.
ride a horse, fly above the gorge on an aerial tour, tour ancient petroglyphs, book a river cruise or hire a guide to fish for sturgeon
Take a guided tour of petroglyphs, including famous She Who Watches, at Columbia Hills State Park then stop at nearby wineries in Tour 7.
hike the gorge’s iconic waterfall trails and less-heralded pathways
Hike to or stop at one of a hundred+ waterfalls along the Historic Columbia River Highway in Tours 10, 11 and 12.
Walk to the top of Beacon Rock, like generations of Northwesterners have done, or walk out to Ives Island at low water, a less traveled option. Both are in Tour 2, North Bonneville and Beacon Rock State Park.
buy fish from a Native American fisher, just as people in the gorge have been doing for 10,000 years
Long before Lewis and Clark passed through the gorge, Native Americans lived and worked here, and many still do. These traditional fishing platforms are at the mouth of the Little White Salmon River, in Tour 5.
pick cherries, pears or apples in orchards on volcanic slopes
Pick cherries in June along a scenic driving route from Mosier to The Dalles, Tour 9.
hang out near the water at one of the gorge towns' many festivals
Stay in luxury at Skamania Lodge and walk to the Gorge Blues and Brews Festival in Stevenson, Tour 3.
stay overnight in a hostel, urban inn or wine country bed and breakfast
Stay at what seems like an oxymoron: a luxurious poor farm, McMenamins Edgefield Manor in Troutdale, seen on Tour 12
About the gorge
The Columbia River Gorge in the Cascade Mountains of the Pacific Northwest is like a national park, with waterfall hiking and biking on curvy, clifftop roads. But in many ways it’s even better: it’s got an 80-mile lineup of riverfront towns that offer urban exploring, Northwest-grown food and drink, and outdoor adventures.   
The gorge divides Washington and Oregon. It’s famous for its waterfalls, windsurfing, wine and the century-old Historic Columbia River Highway, one of the nation’s first scenic highways. 
One of the book's two overview maps: the west end of the gorge. Numbers correspond to the book's chapters.
Towns on the west end sit in rainforest country, with Douglas fir forests and countless waterfalls up to 600 feet high.
One of the book's two overview maps: the east end of the gorge. Numbers correspond to the book's chapters.
The east end of the gorge is the Old West, with empty blue skies, Ponderosa pine, scrub oak, cows and cliffs. 
Scenic road-touring on the Historic Columbia River Highway, between Mosier to The Dalles. Here in the eastern gorge, the rainforest gives way to oaks and rocky canyons. From Tour 9: Mosier and Rowena Crest
The gorge was named the nation’s second National Scenic Area in 1986. It’s also part of the Oregon National Historic Trail, the Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail, and the emerging Ice Age Floods National Geologic Trail. 
Carved by ancient floods, the 80-mile long gorge is one of the Seven Wonders of Oregon—a place where your camera gets a workout and your spirit escapes its to-do lists. From Portland, every location in the book is within 100 miles. 
Inside the book...
These pages from the book still have a few alignment errors--they're from the early rough layout. 
Previous books
I've been writing Pacific Northwest guidebooks since 2001.They've been published by Timber Press, Metro (Portland's regional government) and Microcosm Publishing. 
"...one of the best guidebooks in many years," Salem Statesman Journal
"Foster skillfully combines neighborhood history and architectural descriptions with keen observations guaranteed to capture a walker's imagination." The Oregonian
"A feast of Portland stair facts...with Foster's keen eye for quirky detail" The Oregonian
35,000 copies were printed and distributed free in the Portland region by Metro, funded by a grant from Kaiser Permanente
The book will be published by Microcosm Publishing in 2016, as part of the celebration of Beverly Cleary's 100th birthday.
My books take readers on explorations of a city's or region's geology, architecture, neighborhoods, parklands, and human and natural history. I appeared on Oregon Field Guide in 2006, exploring Portland's street-level past, and again in 2009, rambling around its public stairs. 
Here's what people are saying about my books.
For this book, I started my own publishing company because I wanted to write a guidebook that would include listings of businesses--something none of my earlier books have done. 
The team of experts 
To produce this book I founded Towns to Trails Media and hired a crew of local experts: 
Jenefer Angell of Passionfruit Projects edited the manuscript in fall 2015. Jen and I worked as editors in 2001 at Beyond Words Publishing, and this was my first opportunity to work with her again.
Matthew Hampton designed the book’s maps. A former alpine and white water guide, Matthew’s cartography has won numerous international awards. We worked on Walk There! together. More of his work can be found at Cascade Cartography or at Oregonmetro.gov, where he is the chief cartographer. 
Brad Smith and Etah Chen of Hot Pepper Studios are designing the book’s cover and interior. Brad and I first worked together on Walk There! in 2008.  
Bob Smith of Book Printers Network is handling the book’s printing specs and production at United Graphics in Mattoon, Illinois.
Joe Biel of Microcosm Publishing edited the trailer and Jeff Hayes of Microcosm mastered the audio.  
Timeline
Fall 2013 The seed for this book is planted by Friends of the Columbia Gorge, as one way to promote its Towns to Trails program.
Jan 2014  Awarded grant by Skamania County, on the Washington side of the gorge, to fund research. That was followed by a few months of research, and a lull while I wrapped up other writing projects.
Fall 2014 through Fall 2015  Scouting, research, writing and revising
Fall 2015  Editing and map-making are completed.
Winter 2015 to present  The book's cover and interior are designed. 
February 2016  Kickstarter campaign is launched.
March 2016  The book file is sent to the printer in Illinois. 
Budget
As a writer/publisher, counting my own hours for this project is an exercise I don't attempt. Here are major outside costs to make a beautiful, accurate and detailed book:
Editing: $3,023
Cartography: $5,400
Design of cover and interior: $5,600
Printing: For 3,000 copies: $6,269. For 4,000 copies, $7,511
Ebook conversion: $500
Fees: ISBN, barcode, copyright, incorporation: $480
Total costs, excluding shipping and Kickstarter fees: $21,272 or $22,514, depending on the size of the print run. 
A Stonehenge replica, at Maryhill in the eastern gorge is in Tour 6, a tour of wineries, an improbable art museum associated with Queen Marie of Romania, and one of the nation's best public dark sky observatories.
Rewards
Rewards you can touch are the book as either an ebook or paperback:
and this metal ornament hand-crafted in Cascade Locks, Oregon. 
It's of Tsagaglalal, or She Who Watches, a petroglyph you can see on Tour 7 at Columbia Hills State Park.
Rewards you can remember are interpretive walking or biking tours you can sign up for, to explore Portland and some gorge locales. I've led walking tours for the City of Portland, Metro, Multnomah County Library, Audubon Society of Portland and the Multnomah Athletic Club. They're a great way to laugh, talk to new people, get exercise, see new places and learn a few nuggets of local history. 
Leading one of my favorite Portland Hill Walks: from the King's Hill National Historic District into Washington Park.
Every walking tour must include good food and drink. In this case it's Portland's Gluten Free Gem Bakery.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
The book is in final stages of production: design, where interior pages are laid out. Next stop: printing. The biggest risk, once books are in, and I've fulfilled Kickstarter rewards, is that I'm unable to sell the rest of the books. With this campaign, and early sales calls using advance reading copies, I'll gauge whether a 3,000 or 4,000 (or more) print run is more viable.

It's a risk I believe is acceptable: my other books have great distribution and sales, thanks to their publishers and sales reps. This time, I have to rely on myself, as the sole owner of the book's publisher, Towns to Trails Media, to get the books out of the warehouse and into the hands of potential buyers.

In 2015 while writing the book, I made contacts with booksellers, gift shop owners, inn proprietors, chambers of commerce and tourism executives, and managers of cruise ship lines. 

Once advance reading copies are printed (after design is complete), I'll be traveling the Northwest, pitching the book and asking for orders. I'll give talks and presentations, lead tours, and guest blog--things I've done to promote my other books. It's a calculated leap of faith, but my other books have done well, and I've got the contacts to get this book into the hands of visitors and Portlanders. 

With your pledge to help pay for the book's print run, you're providing a true kickstart to the ongoing work I'll be doing to sell the book.

Thank you!

updates.update_content:
... as my friend (and Curious Gorge author) Scott Cook so charmingly accused me of recently. But after this Gorge book, which has just about 90 copies left to sell of the 3,000-copy print run, I turned back to my first love, Portland.
If you've supported both books, I love you! If not, here's a chance for 18 short (2 miles) to long (17 miles) Portland urban treks, from beaches to peaks, with stairs, hidden paths, pedestrian bridges, and even a totally hidden creek island to explore. It's a total revision of my first stairs book, with much more exploring offered, and all new stories.

Well I was a bit optimistic about timing in my last update; it took longer to address edits after the pages were printed on a print-on-demand printer. Yesterday I received from United Graphics, in Mattoon, Illinois, the proof, which looks great. United Graphics is an offset printer and the difference in quality is striking.
Just one small tweak is needed on the cover to correct a typo, and then United Graphics can start printing books. I'm overnighting the proof back to them today and when I hear from them when books will be shipped to me, I'll post a quick update with that info.

Hi backers,
I'm using offset printing for the book, but for proofing the near-final version, I used the Espresso Book Machine at Powell's City of Books, a print-on-demand printer. Yesterday, with the help of the wonderful Daniela at Powell's, the machine churned out a perfectly gorgeous book. Today I'm proofreading it for the final time, and adding page numbers to the Index. Here are a few pages of the designed book. Once this last round of small edits is done by , the creative forces behind the book's design, it's off to the printer in Mattoon, Illinois next week.

Thank you so much! Your support means the world to me and is a huge boost to the big sales push I'll be doing to get the book out, not to mention allowing me to pay the printer expeditiously!
The campaign funded at 110 percent. Today the book is just about ready to ship to the printer--the designers have been tweaking the maps to ensure they fit the book's design without losing any of the vital info, and that's taken a bit longer than anticipated.

The Kickstarter campaign ends Friday morning and we’re just about to the $7,000 goal. Thank you! I can’t wait to send you a book. If pledges exceed the goal, here's how I'll use the extra funds: the designed book is longer than I'd estimated: instead of 228 pages, it’s 256 pages, which means slightly higher printing costs.

updates.update_content:
Miles of trails take you along Stevenson’s waterfront and the Trail of the Gods
Even if you never bike in Portland, this mellow route from Stevenson to Cascade Locks is made for bike cruising: it's flat, almost all car-free, and biking gives you more time to explore Cascade Locks. It's about 7 miles round-trip as described here. In Cascade Locks, don't miss Lorang Fine Art, Gifts and Antiques and After 10,000 years of fishing in the gorge, Brigham Fish is the gorge's first Native American-owned fish market, selling fish caught locally by members of the Brigham family. I recommend their canned smoked salmon. Also, biking the Trail of the Gods gets you out quickly to Thunder Island, which was once in the midst of the Great Cascades of the Columbia and is now part of the Cascade Locks National Historic Site.

Kwanza Osajyefo, Tim Smith 3, Jamal Igle, Khary Randolph and Sarah Litt have teamed up to produce the graphic novel, BLACK.
After miraculously surviving being gunned down by police, a young man learns that he is part of the biggest lie in history. Now he must decide whether it's safer to keep it a secret or if the truth will set him free.
$45,000: UPGRADE U 
All pledges $25 and up will now include a 8.5” x 11” mini-poster of Jamal’s illustration of Juncture and Kareem. Pledges $50 and above will receive an additional 11” x 17” large-format poster of Khary’s cover.
Additionally, all $25 rewards will include a custom BLACK branded bookmark, and $50 rewards and up will receive three bookmarks, representing each faction within the story.
$55,000: THE BEAUTIFUL STRUGGLE 
Fight scenes in comics can be brief and have a lot of dialogue that wouldn’t be possible in a real fight. It’s been part of Kwanza’s dream to do an epic, cinematic fight scene with minimal dialogue and loads of action.
This goal would add 20 extra pages to the climactic battle at the end of BLACK. Expect all-out action that will give the characters more room to show off their skills and abilities.
PLUS we’ll include a hint at what’s to come after the conclusion of BLACK.
$65,000: BIRTH OF A NATION 
How long have Blacks had superpowers and how has it been kept secret from the world at large? Kwanza Osajyefo and Tim Smith 3 will reveal insights from the lost pages of the Mann family diary dating back as far as the 15th century to present day.
The story will be a limited series published via LINE Webtoons and on BLACK’s social media channels after the graphic novel is released.
$100,000: TOUCH THE SKY
For our final stretch goal we’re aiming at $100,000 to make the book physically bigger – 6.6 x 0.2 x 10.2 inches to be precise. Doing so means adding to weight, printing, and shipping costs but we’d love for people to read BLACK at the same size as most other graphic novels.
CHARACTERS
BLACK is a 120-page story that is comprised of six chapters. If we reach our funding goal, we'll begin work to release issues monthly on digital platforms starting mid-2016.
In advance of the printed book backers will receive issues as DRM-free PDFs in addition to the entire digital volume (with extras!).We're also offering other rewards including prints and special art; please scroll through and pick something you like.
REWARD HIGHLIGHTS
After Reward 2 most subsequent rewards include a limited edition of BLACK. This special version will only be available to Kickstarter pledges of $25 and up. 
Pledges above $50 will receive extra swag with their book, and $100 will get you a copy signed by the whole creative team and your name on the thank you page in the back of the book.
Almost all of the funding amount will go towards illustration, production, and delivery of rewards to our supporters.
THE CREATIVE TEAM
Creator/Author
Creator and writer of BLACK, Kwanza Osajyefo is a former digital editor at Marvel and DC Comics – best known for launching DC's Zuda imprint, which published series like the award-winning Bayou, High Moon, Night Owls, as well as Supertron, Celadore, Black Cherry Bombshells, Bottle of Awesome, and I Rule the Night.
Co-Creator/Designer
Co-creator and designer of BLACK, Tim Smith 3 (A.K.A TS3), has been working in the comic industry for over 15 years. He created and self-published Red After the Party, and has worked on hit titles for some of the biggest publishers in the industry! To see more of TS3’s work, check out: JUNEMOON.NET.
Interior Illustrator
Recipient of the 2011 Inkpot Award for Outstanding Achievement in Comic Art, Jamal Igle is the writer/artist/Creator of Molly Danger for Action Lab Entertainment. He’s pencilled everything from indie faves to Marvel, DC hits, and now BLACK. He is VP of Marketing and Publicity for Action Lab Entertainment.
Cover Illustrator
Since graduating from School of Visual Arts with a BFA in Cartooning and Illustration, Khary’s been involved in TV, marketing, and comics. The cover artist for BLACK, he’s worked on everything from TMNT to The Boondocks and Hellboy, as well as designs for Brooklyn Brewery – most recently he’s worked on Robin Wars for DC. He's currently developing a new title for Marvel.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
The biggest risk to BLACK is not reaching its funding goal. We've assembled a dedicated team of comics veterans who can deliver this project. We've also hired a fulfillment company to handle delivery of all rewards. 

Almost all funds will go to compensating these professionals for their time.

Another risk is the continued lack of diversity in the comics profession and in content. Our core principle is to tell an entertaining story – but the material and creative team also represent an effort for Black creators to own our narrative and have agency in the industry.

We thank you in advance for your support. #goBLACK

updates.update_userinfo: GETTING THE BAND BACK TOGETHER...ON AND OFF THE PAGE
updates.update_content: Almost four years ago, Kwanza Osajyefo and Tim Smith 3 came to my apartment and pitched me a simple, but brilliant, concept. “What if Only Black People had superpowers?,” a simple, obvious concept that I was surprised  no one had ever pitched before, as far as I knew. At that moment I knew I had to be involved with the project. That simple pitch became the first part of what we’ve dubbed “The Black Superpowers Universe:” six issues, 140 pages leading to three spinoffs and a lot of attention.

updates.update_userinfo: AND WE BACK, AND WE BACK
updates.update_content:
Whaddup, y’all!
We’ve just launched our Kickstarter for WHITE, the second part of the trilogy that started with our critically acclaimed graphic novel, BLACK.
It’s hard to believe that three years ago we took a chance that people might back the concept: “what if only black people had superpowers.” It was an idea partially borne out of not seeing black people in positions with agency and how that results in a lack of representation in comics.

We’ve received an update from our distribution partner that books are going out this week!
Sorry for the delay.
Printing, shipping, and packing all of the copies slammed our small operation, but we’re determined and glad that limited editions of BLACK are finally rolling out.

campaign.story:
People of Colo(u)r Destroy Science Fiction! is saying, “We’re here. We have always been here. And we are very, very excited to show it.”
What does it mean, for you, yes, you—the reader, the avid science fiction fan, purveyor of the imaginative even when faced by the banality of a day-to-day life—to support a publication that is colored, and we mean, like really, really colored, by the nuances of culture, race, and history? For one, you get to read something that would dispel the notion of POC-penned science fiction as somewhat inferior science fiction. We will work very hard to come up with a lineup that will counter this assumption, and we will succeed in doing so.
We believe in science fiction’s transformative powers, its ability to remedy the dreariness of our lives. People of Colo(u)r Destroy Science Fiction! will exist, with your kind help, of course, to relieve a brokenness we’ve enabled time and time again by favoring certain voices and portrayals of particular characters. We won’t harangue you with guilt trips involving the importance of openly listening to the assimilated, the colonized, the misappropriated. That’s just not how we roll. What we aim to do, instead, is to challenge you: Join us because it is fun to do so. We don’t mean fun as a vehicle for trivializing centuries of injustice that resulted in the lack of representation for certain groups of people because power structures were skewed heavily in favor of a chosen few. We mean fun as the satisfaction we get in those light-bulb-in-the-head moments of our lives, the satisfaction we get from meaningful conversations that lend clarity, the satisfaction we get when we move past those feel-good-driven acts of tokenism, the satisfaction we get when we read stories that have palpable artistic and intellectual values that speak of our present time and most of all, our future.
As we said in our submission call, we will not be asking writers who submit stories to tell us what makes them “people of colo(u)r.” We leave that up to your world experience, your conscience, your sense of community, and your sense of fair play. And like the other hugely successful initiatives of Lightspeed’s Destroy series, People of Colo(u)r Destroy Science Fiction! is saying, “We’re here. We have always been here. And we are very, very excited to show it.”
Join us by supporting our Kickstarter.
P.S. If you're excited too, and not just in the I GOTTA HAVE THIS THING sort of way but in the I GOTTA BE PART OF THIS kind of way, good news! If you write fiction, we're currently open to submissions for the issue. If you don't write fiction, or even if you do, but you want to help out in some other way, the best thing you can do is help spread the word about this campaign. And if you have other ways you'd like to help, we're happy to listen!
We’ll publish the special issue whether the campaign is successful or not, but the campaign will determine how big and awesome we make the issue. If we raise just $5000, we’ll be able to make the special issue a special double-sized issue,and if we raise even more than that, we have a few really excellent stretch goals lined up as well.
In 2014, we conducted a successful campaign to fund our first special issue, Women Destroy Science Fiction!, which ended up raising more than 1000% of our original goal, and unlocked additional special issues Women Destroy Horror! and Women Destroy Fantasy!
In 2015, we conducted another successful campaign to fund Queers Destroy Science Fiction!. It performed similarly to WDSF, raising more than 1000% of our goal, and unlocked additional special issues Queers Destroy Horror! and Queers Destroy Fantasy!
A regular issue of LIGHTSPEED contains an equal mix of science fiction and fantasy short fiction, consisting of 4 original stories, 4 reprints, plus a novella reprint (exclusive to our ebook edition). Each issue also includes a feature interview, a book review column, a media review column, and spotlights on the authors who appear in the issue.
The special issue will contain the following:
All science fiction (no fantasy)
5 original, never-before-published short stories
About 5,000 words of original flash fiction (about 5 flash stories)
2 previously-published short stories
1 previously-published novella
Author Spotlights on our authors in this issue
Assorted nonfiction features
An original cover illustration
If we successfully fund, the special DOUBLE issue will contain the following additional material:
5 additional original, never-before-published short stories (for a total of 10)
About 5,000 additional words of original flash fiction (for a total of about 10 flash stories)
2 additional previously-published short stories (for a total of 4)
Author Spotlights on the additional authors
Even more assorted nonfiction features
Plus, if we unlock one of our stretch goals, the issue will include additional material as well.
And naturally, all of the above will all be authored entirely by POC creators.
For this special issue, control of the magazine has been handed over to a talented team of POC creators:
Nalo Hopkinson, Co-Editor-in-Chief/Original Fiction Editor
Nalo Hopkinson is a Jamaican-born Canadian whose taproots extend to Trinidad and Guyana. She has published numerous novels and short stories, and has edited and co-edited anthologies, including Whispers From the Cotton Tree Root: Caribbean Fabulist Fiction, and Mojo: Conjure Stories. Her writing has received the John W. Campbell Memorial Award, the Locus Award, the World Fantasy Award, the Sunburst Award for Excellence in Canadian Literature of the Fantastic, and the Andre Norton Award. Hopkinson is a professor of Creative Writing at the University of California, Riverside. She has taught at both the Clarion Writers’ Workshop and the Clarion West Writers’ Workshop. Hopkinson’s short story collection Falling in Love With Hominids was published in 2015 by Tachyon Books. Learn more at nalohopkinson.com.
Kristine Ong Muslim, Co-Editor-in-Chief/Original Fiction Editor
Kristine Ong Muslim is the author of We Bury the Landscape (Queen’s Ferry Press, 2012), Grim Series (Popcorn Press, 2012), and A Roomful of Machines (ELJ Publications, 2015). Her forthcoming books include the short story collection Age of Blight (Unnamed Press, 2016) and two poetry collections from university presses in the Philippines. Her stories appeared in One Buck Horror, Confrontation Magazine, The State, and elsewhere. She lives in southern Philippines and serves as poetry editor of LONTAR: The Journal of Southeast Asian Speculative Fiction, a literary journal published by Epigram Books in Singapore. Learn more at kristinemuslim.weebly.com.
Nisi Shawl, Reprint Editor
Nisi Shawl is a founder of the Carl Brandon Society and a member of Clarion West’s Board of Directors. Since its 2011 inception she has edited reviews for feminist literary quarterly The Cascadia Subduction Zone. Books Shawl has edited include Bloodchildren: Stories by the Octavia E. Butler Scholars; and WisCon Chronicles 5: Writing and Racial Identity; she also co-edited Strange Matings: Science Fiction, Feminism, African American Voices, and Octavia E. Butler; and Stories for Chip: A Tribute to Samuel R. Delany. With Cynthia Ward she coauthored 2005 Tiptree Longlist book Writing the Other: A Practical Approach. Her story collection Filter House co-won the 2009 Tiptree Award. Shawl’s Belgian Congo steampunk novel Everfair is due out from Tor in September 2016.
Berit Ellingsen, Flash Fiction Editor
Berit Ellingsen’s novel Not Dark Yet was published by Two Dollar Radio in November 2015. Berit is the author of the short story collection Beneath the Liquid Skin (firthFORTH Books) and the novel Une Ville Vide (PublieMonde), with work in W.W. Norton’s Flash Fiction International, SmokeLong Quarterly, Unstuck, The Humanity of Monsters, and other places. Berit’s stories have been nominated for the Pushcart Prize, Best of the Net, and the British Science Fiction Association Award. The author divides time between Norway and Svalbard in the Arctic, and is a member of the Norwegian Authors’ Union. Learn more at beritellingsen.com.
Sunil Patel, Personal Essays Editor
Sunil Patel is a Bay Area fiction writer and playwright who has written about everything from ghostly cows to talking beer. His plays have been performed at San Francisco Theater Pub and San Francisco Olympians Festival, and his fiction has appeared or is forthcoming in Fireside Magazine, Orson Scott Card’s Intergalactic Medicine Show, Flash Fiction Online, The Book Smugglers, Fantastic Stories of the Imagination, and Asimov’s Science Fiction, among others. Plus he reviews books for Lightspeed and is Assistant Editor of Mothership Zeta. His favorite things to consume include nachos, milkshakes, and narrative. Find out more at ghostwritingcow.com, where you can watch his plays, or follow him @ghostwritingcow. His Twitter has been described as “engaging,” “exclamatory,” and “crispy, crunchy, peanut buttery.”
Grace Dillon, Nonfiction Editor
Grace L. Dillon (Anishinaabe) is a Professor in the Indigenous Nations Studies Program, School of Gender, Race, and Nations, at Portland State University in Portland, Oregon, where she teaches graduate and undergraduate courses on a range of interests including Native American and Indigenous studies, science fiction, Indigenous cinema, popular culture, race and social justice, and early modern literature. She is the editor of Walking the Clouds: An Anthology of Indigenous Science Fiction (University of Arizona Press, 2012) and Hive of Dreams: Contemporary Science Fiction from the Pacific Northwest (Oregon State University Press, 2003). Her work appears in diverse journals including The Journal of Science Fiction Film and Television; Foundation: The International Review of Science Fiction; Extrapolation; The Journal of the Fantastic in the Arts; The Historical Journal of Film, Radio and Television; Science Fiction Studies; Parabola; and Renaissance Papers.
LIGHTSPEED (lightspeedmagazine.com) is a digital science fiction and fantasy magazine. In its pages, you will find science fiction: from near-future, sociological soft SF, to far-future, star-spanning hard SF—and fantasy: from epic fantasy, sword-and-sorcery, and contemporary urban tales, to magical realism, science-fantasy, and folktales. When you read LIGHTSPEED, it is our hope that you’ll see where science fiction and fantasy comes from, where it is now, and where it’s going.
LIGHTSPEED is a two-time winner of the Hugo Award, and stories from LIGHTSPEED have been nominated for the Hugo Award, the Nebula Award, the Theodore Sturgeon Award, and the World Fantasy Award. Previously, we crowdfunded our two other "Destroy" special issues: In 2014, we published Women Destroy Science Fiction!, which was named one of NPR's best books of 2014 and won the British Fantasy Award; and in 2015, we published Queers Destroy Science Fiction!, which received similar acclaim.
When not doing special issues devoted to destroying science fiction, LIGHTSPEED is usually edited by bestselling anthologist John Joseph Adams, editor of anthologies such as Wastelands, The Living Dead, and Brave New Worlds, and series editor of Best American Science Fiction & Fantasy.
All of the money raised by this project will be used to fund the publication of the POC Destroy Science Fiction! special issue and related stretch goals. Anything leftover after that will go toward the production of future issues of LIGHTSPEED.
You'll find our various reward options in a column on the right side of this page (PC/Mac) or on a separate page (iOS/Android). Below are some explanations and clarifications of our various reward options.

campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
The POC Destroy Science Fiction! special issue is scheduled to publish June 1, 2016. LIGHTSPEED has been publishing monthly issues since June 2010, and we haven't missed an issue or had an issue come out late in all that time, so there's no reason to suspect that we'll start now. We also hit all of our reward fulfillment deadlines for our previous "Destroy" projects.

But not only should you not worry about us delivering; you also shouldn't worry about the quality. LIGHTSPEED won the 2014 and 2015 Hugo Awards for Best Semiprozine, and our Women Destroy Science Fiction! special issue received all kinds of acclaim—including being named one of the best books of 2014 by NPR and winning the British Fantasy Award. So all signs point to the POC Destroy Science Fiction! issue being another awesome one.

During the invasion of Iraq in 2003, the College of Fine Arts at the University of Baghdad lost their entire library from looters who set fire to the collection. Over 70,000 books were reduced to ashes. To this day, students still have few books from which to study.
168:01 is an installation at the Art Gallery of Windsor featuring a library of blank white books. The white library stands as an austere monument of loss that simultaneously activates a potential for rebirth. Each book in the white library is embedded with the possibility of rebuilding anew from the ashes of cultural decimation.
This is where you come in – 168:01 is a system of exchange, connecting viewers like yourselves directly with the College of Fine Arts to generate a transnational grassroots effort. Your participation in this Kickstarter will fund educational texts from a wish list compiled by faculty at the College of Fine Arts. Each new text will replace a blank white book from the exhibition. 
Our goal is to replace all 1,000 blank books in the exhibition with educational texts. At the end of the exhibition, all of the texts will be shipped to the College of Fine Arts in Baghdad, beginning the process of rebuilding their library.
---
Historical Context
During the Islamic Golden Age, Baghdad was home to the largest library in the world—the Bayt al-Hikma, or House of Wisdom. A Mongol siege in the 13th century laid waste to all the libraries of Baghdad, along with the House of Wisdom. According to legend, the library was thrown into the Tigris River to create a bridge of books for the Mongolian army to cross. The pages bled ink into the river for seven days, after which the books were drained of knowledge.
168:01 takes its title from this story of loss, representing the first second after 168 hours (or seven days), which signals the beginning of rebirth and process of moving forward to rebuild.
---
About the Artist
Wafaa Bilal is renowned for provoking dialogue about international politics and internal dynamics through high profile, technologically-driven art projects that employ the use of robotics, the Internet, and photographic mobile mapping. His work is informed by the experience of fleeing his homeland of Iraq and existing simultaneously in two worlds—his home in the “comfort zone” of the United States and his consciousness of the “conflict zone” in Iraq.
Bilal’s work is represented in major public collections, including Mathaf: Arab Museum of Modern Art, Qatar; Museum of Contemporary Photography, Chicago; Milwaukee Art Museum; and the Los Angeles County Museum of Art, California. He has exhibited extensively in galleries and institutions throughout the world, including the US, Thailand, Iraq, the UK, Dubai, Lebanon, France, and Germany, and he has served on the panels of over twenty major global universities and institutions, including the Tate Modern, UK; Harvard University; Stanford University; Museum of Art and Design; the Global Art Forum, Qatar; and the Inter-Society for the Electronic Arts, Turkey. His work has been reviewed in major publications, including ARTnews¸ Art in America, The New York Times, The Wall Street Journal, and Newsweek, and he is the co-author of the critically-acclaimed 2008 publication "Shoot an Iraqi: Arts, Life and Resistance Under the Gun"
About the Art Gallery of Windsor
The Art Gallery of Windsor collects, conserves, interprets and presents Canadian art. It is a place to view significant works of art by local, regional, national and international artists; a place to see what Canadians have been making and thinking about for longer than Canada has been a country. The AGW is a valuable cultural resource for the Windsor area, providing the special service of showcasing Canadian art in a city that has one of the busiest border crossings between Canada and the United States.
Located in the southern tip of Canada and across the river from Detroit, is an important site for the arrival and departure for Indigenous, settler and migrant communities. In recent years many Middle Eastern families fled their countries in search of safety in the US and Canada. Both Windsor and Detroit are home to burgeoning Middle Eastern communities that now form an essential part of their cultural fabric. Wafaa Bilal’s installation 168.01 will resonate deeply with the Gallery’s audiences and open up important conversations on freedom, security and cultural heritage that are at once deeply interwoven and splintered along colonial, racial and economic lines. This project is commissioned by the Art Gallery of Windsor and curated by Srimoyee Mitra, Curator of Contemporary Art.
The Art Gallery of Windsor is a chartered, non-profit, educational organization operating for the benefit of the public. It is supported by its members, donors and sponsors, the City of Windsor, The Canada Council for the Arts, the Department of Canadian Heritage, the Ontario Arts Council, and the Ministry of Citizenship, Culture and Recreation.
For more information on the exhibition visit: 168:01
---

campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
The success of 168:01 relies heavily on community support, so the biggest obstacle to full realization of this project would be underfunding. To replace every white book on the shelf with a book from The University of Baghdad’s wish list, I will need to raise over $20,000. Ideally, I will raise more than the goal.

By keeping the funding goal modest on Kickstarter, I am giving myself 1) a good jumping off point to start purchasing the books for the exhibition and 2) time to secure the rest of books as direct donations. I am hoping to build off the momentum of a successful campaign, grab the attention of the right people and continue circulating the registry of books to individuals and organizations throughout the exhibition period. 

The shipping of the white book rewards from 168:01 may be delayed, as the exhibition will travel to at least one other venue after the Art Gallery of Windsor. I will make sure to keep donors in the loop on any developments.

campaign.story:
What was in Room 3327?
On January 7th, 1943, an eighty-six-year-old man died penniless in the New Yorker Hotel. Within hours of his death, government agents seized everything in that room. But multiple accounts suggest a certain notebook, rumored to be there, was missing.    
The occupant of that room... was Nikola Tesla.
Nearly seventy-five years later, in the hard-luck city of Buffalo, NY, a low-rent detective witnesses his partner killed in the crossfire of a blackmail scheme gone bad. Driven to know why, he's led into a twisted conspiracy to possess a world-changing design torn from Tesla's fabled missing notebook... 
That design is the object everyone is after - Hitchcock's 'MacGuffin' - in THE AMERICAN SIDE.
Set against the classic and industrial architectural backdrop of Buffalo and the mesmerizing power of Niagara Falls, THE AMERICAN SIDE is populated with complexly motivated characters played by an eclectic ensemble of actors from Matthew Broderick to Camilla Belle, Janeane Garofalo to Robert Forster, and even the original Man from U.N.C.L.E., Robert Vaughn!
Yes!
Grab your popcorn!                                                                                     
This film has already been made!  
Our campaign isn’t about raising funds to make a film. It’s about making sure we get this film into a theater near you!
When it premiered at the Woodstock Film Festival, THE AMERICAN SIDE was hailed by The Hollywood Reporter as an 'adrenaline-charged, pop-noir mystery' and a festival ‘highlight’, loaded with loving homages to film noir, Hitchcock, and conspiracy films of the '70s. 
It also sent audiences scrambling down the rabbit hole into the wildly intriguing world of Tesla.
Who was Nikola Tesla?
Responsible in whole or in part for almost every significant technological advancement of the 20th century, Tesla was developing wireless devices when people were still getting around on horseback. But eventually the eccentric and paranoid genius was marginalized by his peers and abandoned by the industrialists who made millions from his work.
Still, Tesla continued to invent, obscuring his designs by leaving them unlabeled, unfinished, and even separated into pieces. The later works of his that were recovered, are studied by the U.S. Government to this day.
PLAY

We all know countless terrific films are made every year that don’t have a promotional machine behind them, and therefore never make it to the big screen. But there is a growing movement in the indie film world to change the typical model and take charge of the theatrical life of these films. 
For our spring theatrical release, we’re partnering with one of the sharpest, most experienced minds in independent film. Because before you see it someplace like HBO or Netflix, THE AMERICAN SIDE should first live where it was meant to be seen: in movie theaters. 
By raising our own financing for publicists, posters, trailers, ads, and fancy things like digital packages so theaters can project the movie properly, we can reach audiences beyond the initial markets. Every dollar we raise expands our presence. More backing means more theaters and a larger life for the film. 
It also means REWARDS for you! 
THE AMERICAN SIDE is a truly independent endeavor from a filmmaking team without insider connections or piles of dough, just a dogged commitment to the material and the belief that there is an audience for intricate indie films that entertain.
Please take a look at our rewards and back this project with whatever you can, so we may reach that audience - in movie theaters - where films like THE AMERICAN SIDE should be experienced for the first time.
And keep in mind, you can pledge above the price point of the reward you choose, or wave your reward altogether.
So many extraordinary actors, designers, and technicians shared our belief and signed on. We hope you will too.
Join the conspiracy.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
They say it's a miracle ANY film EVER gets made. So many things have to go right, and you can still lose it all because of three days of rain. 

Some people thought making a film this ambitious on a tight budget and an even tighter schedule was crazy. But as Robert Forster's character puts it, 'One man's nuts, is another man's balls.'

We were told on more than one occasion-
'You’ll never be able to shoot that scene on your budget’.
‘You’ll never get that actor’.
‘Greg Stuhr is so handsome he’ll distract from the story’.

And yet, thanks to a lot of grit, determination, an incredible group of artists and technicians (including a makeup team that made Greg look like 'just a guy'), and a heck of a cast, crew, and post-production team, we overcame every one of those challenges to complete THE AMERICAN SIDE.

Still, even after facing down the long odds of getting the film made the way we wanted it made, one huge challenge remained: ensuring THE AMERICAN SIDE had a life in theaters.

*********************************************

Ever stumble across a great film on cable or Netflix and wonder why you’d never heard of it? Too often the answer is simply ‘money’. Major studios control what we see at the movies, even putting out so-called ‘indie’ films that are simply produced by a studio subsidiary. Studios have the resources to promote these films, making them more attractive to theater owners and further limiting the number of screens available for truly independent work. 

To compete, indie filmmakers who have already stretched every penny to make their film, are now tasked with raising more to promote their films beyond a limited release in a couple of select markets.

But again, by the nature of producing in the independent realm, we get pretty good at tackling obstacles. And if we've learned anything, it's that for every problem there is a solution. 

Part of our goal is to empower you, our audience, to decide if THE AMERICAN SIDE looks like a film you’d like to see in theaters. Your pledge is a 'yes' to that, and to seeing independent films AT THE MOVIES! 

********************************************************

*This fundraising campaign is subject to all Kickstarter rules and regulations, movie guild rules, and applicable laws. In the event of difficulties or conflicts regarding reward fulfillment, we pledge to work with you in good faith to resolve the issue or give you a substitute reward. 

*For those of you joining us for a premiere, location tour, or on set, we will do our best to keep you informed of our schedule. As stated in the rewards, we are not responsible for transportation or lodging. 

*For those of you choosing the glamorous life of a movie extra, you'll have to sign a release for the powers-that-be. And we cannot guarantee you'll end up in the final cut, but we'll sure try. You'll need to be a U.S. citizen or have a U.S. work visa. And you cannot be a member of SAG/AFTRA.

*Though all physical rewards are noted as shipping only within the U.S., we may be able to make exceptions. If you choose a reward that includes a t-shirt or mini-poster and you live outside the U.S., contact us at theamericanside@gmail.com for details.

*Please consider the age appropriateness for rewards. We reserve the right to alter rewards where deemed necessary.
